captions.text:
Japanese submarine slammed
two torpedoes into her side.

Was comin' back from
the island ofTinian Leyte.

Just delivered the bomb,
the Hiroshima bomb.

Eleven hundred men
went into the water.

Vessel went down
in 1 2 minutes.

Didn't see the first shark
for about halfan hour.

Tiger, 1 3-footer.
Know how you know that
when you're in the water ?

You tell by lookin' from
the dorsal to the tail.

What we didn't know was our bomb
mission had been so secret...

no distress signal
had been sent.

They didn't even list us
as overdue for a week.

Vey first light, Chief,
sharks come cruisin'.

We formed ourselves
into tight groups.

Kinda like old squares
in a battle,

like you see on a calendar,
like the Battle of Waterloo.

The idea was,
shark comes to the nearest man,

that man starts poundin',
hollerin', screamin'.

Sometimes the shark
go away,

sometimes he
wouldn't go away.

Sometimes that shark
Iooks right into ya,
right into your eyes.

You know, a thing about a shark,
he's got lifeless eyes.

Black eyes,
like a doll's eyes.

When he comes at ya,
doesn't seem to be livin'

until he bites ya and
those black eyes roll over wide.
And then--

then you hear that terrible
high-pitched screamin'.
The ocean turns red.

ln spite of the pounding
and hollering, they all come in.

They rip you
to pieces.

You know, by the end
of that first dawn,
lost a hundred men.

l don't know how many sharks,
maybe a thousand.

l don't know how many men.
They averaged six an hour.
On Thursday morning,

l bumped into a friend ofmine,
Robinson, from Cleveland,

baseball player,
boatswain's mate.

l thought
he was asleep.

Reached over
to wake him up.

Bobbed up and down
in the water like a top.
Upended.

Well, he'd been bitten
in half below the waist.

Noon the fifth day,
Mr. Hooper,

a Lockheed Ventura
SaW US.

He swung in low
and saw us.

Young pilot,
a lot younger than Mr. Hooper.

He saw us and come in low.
Three hours later,

a big fat PBY comes down
and starts to pick us up.

That was the time
l was most frightened,
waitin' for my turn.

l'll never put on
a lifejacket again.

Eleven hundred men
went into the water.

31 6 men come out.
The sharks took the rest.

Anyway,
we delivered the bomb.

title: The Indianapolis Speech - Jaws (7/10) Movie CLIP (1975) HD

comments.text: "I'll never put on that life jacket again.."﻿
comments.author: TailsFan456

comments.text:
What hell awaits the poor sailors of a recently felled ship? What hope do 
they hold onto while they watch their home submerge? What thoughts do they 
roost upon as they contemplate death, capture, or rescue? And what, in the 
end, do they come away with?

I am thankful for those who experienced these things so that I might not 
have to.﻿
comments.author: Altrunchen

comments.text: Genius.﻿

comments.author: ACNC1

comments.text: Dreyfuss's intense fascination in the detail makes the scene even better.﻿
comments.author: Matt Jarrett

comments.text: love this part ﻿
comments.author: terrance mobley

comments.text:
The most captivating and emotionally inducing scene I have ever seen. The 
best in the movie and the best in the history of cinema. This was the 
moment I was most frightened. The mystery of the ocean and the uncertainty 
of a mysterious killer shark surrounding them as Quint delivers one of the 
most horrific but lesser known stories in WWII. Even as a kid, I remembered 
and understood every single word said. I couldn't take my eyes off the 
screen. This was the scene that gave me nightmares of sharks swimming in my 
room, hunting me down with nothing but the veil of my blanket keeping me 
safe. My father always taught me to respect the ocean and to this day I 
still do. Jaws gave me that more than the fear itself. It made me fear the 
ocean but did it respectably. It was a fear that was and is well deserved. 
The ocean is a beautiful place but also a place of unpredictability. This 
movie was a horror film of the highest caliber because it presented you 
with a situation that wasn't over the top stupid nor did it treat the 
audience like brainless idiots, but gave you a problem that was very real 
and very possible. The greatest movie of all time in my opinion. Spielberg 
went through hell to make it, but managed to make it pay off timelessly. 
Forever will he be indebted to this film for making him the big time 
director he is today.﻿
comments.author: Joseph Franc

comments.text:
THE USS INDIANAPOLIS DID SOMETHING EXTRAORDINARILY IMPORTANT IN HELPING TO 
BRING WW2 TO A RAPID END......IT BROUGHT THE ATOMIC BOMB THAT WAS DROPPED 
ON HIROSHIMA ACROSS THE PACIFIC FROM SAN FRANCISCO TO TINIAN ISLAND, FROM 
WHERE THE ENOLA GAY TOOK OFF WITH THE "LITTLE BOY" (THE BOMB'S NICKNAME) 
FOR THE MISSION TO HIROSHIMA.﻿

comments.author: michael fitzgerald

comments.text:
If your interested in the shark attacks associated with the sinking of the 
U.S.S. Indianapolis, then perhaps you might also be interested to learn 
that there was a Japanese analog: The Battle of Ramree Island. Wherein on 
19 February 1945, 900 Imperial Japanese soldiers fled into a swamp in order 
to flee from the advancing British Army and in so doing, they (the 
Japanese) found their numbers dwindled down to 20 survivors the following 
morning, after a night of being attacked by saltwater crocodiles. ﻿
comments.author: Michael Heffernan

comments.text:
What I love about this scene is that it's great second-hand story-telling 
with in a movie. We get to listen to the story as an audience along with 
the other characters, but also get to see their reaction to it.﻿

comments.author: Trev Mac

comments.text:
What an absolutely magnetic performance, Shaw's entire delivery was 
completely and utterly captivating. We don't have many actors like him 
anymore... if I'm not mistaken he wrote the Indianapolis speech himself, 
what a true talent he was. I also read that the first take of this scene he 
was literally drunk instead of them just having been a bit tipsy after 
drinking in the movie, he called Spieldberg that night to apologize and 
asked if they could try the take again the next day... well he came in the 
next day sober and that next take was the electrifying one we see today. 
Apparently Dreyfus and Shaw also had disputes off camera which made the 
chemistry of the mutual disdain for each other all the more volatile. One 
of the best overall movies of all time up there with One Flew Over the 
Cuckoo's Nest, the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, the Shawshenk Redemption, 
Godfather part 1 and 2, Pulp Fiction, and Dark Knight just to name a few. 
It takes a lot to make a good movie, especially standout performances by 
the likes of Robert Shaw here.﻿
comments.author: LSSRoshi

comments.text: Yea, I wasn't sure. I heard it before they made that documentary.

comments.text:
I never understood why at the part where he says that a P.B.Y came to pick

comments.author: Serenity113

comments.text:
I think the implication here is that your fear is at it's highest when 
there's some hope you'll make it out of the situation alive. When you're 
floating out at sea, with seemingly no hope of rescue, you're scared, of 
course. But you've also likely made peace and come to terms with the idea 
that you're probably going to die. But when you're floating in the water, 
watching the men ahead of you being loaded into a rescue plane, and 
watching the men behind you being slowly picked off by sharks, you so 
desperately want to make it to the plane before the sharks make it to you 
and your fear is at it's highest.
comments.author: David Flores

comments.text:
What I always thought about this : I think he's talking about the time that 
he had to wait the rescue team. He jumped in the P.B.Y or he was rescued 
after this...same story, you have to wait in this water and at any second 
you still can be killed.
It's the most frightening moment : you know you have a chance and you 
realize the danger considering the amount of your comrades dying every hour.
And the lifejacket...I think that he was so traumatized by this horrible 
tragedy that he doesn't want to wear this again, cause it would remind him 
all these dead people...and have this feeling again to dance with death, 
but you're not calling the tune.
comments.author: LetotheBlue

comments.author: Serenity113

comments.text:
As the PBY came in. PBY was a plane that could land in water. He said that 
he was most frightened. As the PBY was picking up sailors the sharks were 
still attacking the men in the water. Most sailors thought feared that they 
would be taken by a shark insight of the plane. He said that he would never 
wear a life vest again. The life vests that the men were wear were only 
good up to 48 hours in the water. By rescue most men's life vest had 
started to fail. Most men thought it was easier to die than to continue 
survive. Read the book "In harms way" it explains what the men went through.

comments.text:
I recall an interview in which Spielberg relayed that Robert Shaw's 
character was supposed to be pretty drunk in the scene, so Shaw, being the 
heavy drinker he was, got blitzed before shooting & the scene did not work 
whatsoever. So, they reshot it some time thereafter with Shaw being stone 
cold sober & this was the final result... Either way, an absolutely 
incredible monologue, it's one of my favorites. ﻿

comments.author: Alex Mille

comments.text:
Spielberg asked milius to fix that speech cause it was too short. Milius 
wrote 10 pages on the phone, and both shaw and spielberg were mesmerized. 
Shaw admitted he could not memorize all that stuff, so they decided to trim 
all the monologue in half, and that's what we see in the movie. All this is 
told by Spielberg in interview ;)
comments.author: Alex Mille

comments.text:
There's some controversy there as to who wrote how much of that speech with 
some giving Shaw himself the credit
comments.author: Arthur Grant

comments.text:
The best thing about this scene is that it gives Quint a sense of humility 
after he'd been at odds with Hooper the enitre movie leading up to this.  
It also gives Jaws a leg up over most horror movies because in a movie with 
a bunch of people yelling "Sharrrrk" where we see kids and adults getting 
attacked by  Great White Shark etc. - and don't really see the shark - 
realistic and brilliant imho - this is THE best scene in the film - 
dialogue about something horrific that happened 30 years earlier told with 
such colorful penache by the great Robert Shaw.  I love how he keeps 
referring to Hooper in the speech..implying his age and how young Quint was 
at the time of the incident - and how it so bothered him to see other men 
that young being taken before their time.  It was like the College boy vs. 
The Man of the Sea thing went right out the window.  Film should be proud 
that it has Jaws to look back on as one of it's top achievements.﻿
comments.author: Wine Layman

comments.author: chrono4203

comments.text:
Damn, you see acting on this level only rarely anymore and from only 2 or 3 
actors that I can think of. Shaw alone creates the amazing tension in this 
scene and he's telling the story so earnestly that you can vividly imagine 
the scenes. Touches like that sick, tortured smile he gives after the 
line-- "In spite of all the poundin' and the hollerin', they all come in 
and they rip you to pieces."-- are genius and give the speech an awesome 
realism.﻿

(his was 10 pages long and was done pretty last minute.) I'm not gonna lie 
and say that Shaw didn't nail this speech, but I will say that he didn't 
write it. He just edited it, and he didn't even improvise his edits.

different level..
comments.author: gabbygall

comments.text:
Not improvised at all. John Milius (writer of Apocalypse Now, Dirty Harry, 
and many other classics) wrote the entire speech on the phone with Steven 
Spielberg. Shaw simply cut it down from 10 pages to 5.

comments.author: Solid State

comments.text:
This film was largely, although probably unintentionally, responsible for 
bringing national and worldwide awareness to the tragedy of the sinking of 
the Indianapolis and the terrible loss of life from amongst the crew.
The sinking of the Indianapolis happening at the end of the war was kind of 
hushed up in the media by the military and people were largely consumed 
with the final peace and end to WW2. So, it was largely forgotten by the 
general public.
In large part, Robert Shaw can be thanked for that in making it such a 
powerful scene. Apparently is was not only due to his great acting, but 
also his writing as others here have revealed that he re-wrote the 
monologue.
It is imho, one of the greatest monologues ever delivered in film. Great 
silent support too from Dreyfuss and Scheider.﻿
comments.author: lemaxmas

comments.text: One of the best performances in film history. ﻿
comments.author: Janet Halley

comments.text:
Not to slam any World War II Veteran (as almost 99.9% of them were just 
doing what the rich men who run the world were telling them to do) but I 
don't see why the sharks are being demonized for eating the sailors of 
the Indianapolis. Those sailors were in the Ocean and the Ocean (believe it 
or not) is still very much a dangerous place (with everything from Man 
o'War Jelly Fish plumes to horrific undercurrents that can drag a 300+ lb 
man underwater and never again bring him up). Furthermore, sharks are 
predators and scavengers so demonizing them for eating red meat (even if 
it's human meat) while the sharks are in their own environment and the 
humans are the invaders is not okay. I'm sorry and I sympathize with what 
those sailors must have went through and I also sympathize what their 
families had to endure but they knew the risks and decided to enlist 
instead of remaining safe on land (even if that land was a prison). If you 
want to blame someone for the sharks eating the sailors of the Indianapolis 
then blame the people who started the war (which were on both sides).﻿
comments.author: Debonair Damsel

comments.text: The Best Scene of the hole Movie﻿

that survived it.. ﻿

I hauled 'er in. Many Missouri kitties were lost due to these catfish. Der 
Kitty nephews' eyes would pop out, do to stories such as this.﻿

comments.author: Krystal Harwood

comments.text:
That scene was added after the original cut. Filmed in a swimming pool with 
milk added to simulate Martha's Vineyard murky waters. Spielberg had to pay 
the 3k to film it because the studio was done and frustrated. Test 
audiences in Dallas and California saw the movie without this and also with 
less time before Scheider's improvised, "you're going to need a bigger 
boat." Spielberg added a few seconds because the audiences were still 
screaming from seeing the shark come out of the water.

comments.author: Josh Weiner

comments.text: Still think this stands as the best acting scene in all of cinema. ﻿

When I was a kid, my cousins and I had the option to see Bambie or Jaws. 
Why in the name of God that was our choices I will never know. We obviously 
chose Jaws. I remember this scene being the most terrifying thing about 
Jaws. The way he describes the sharks as they come in for the kill 
mortified me. Watching it now, it has the same effect. Shaw was an 
underrated actor. Quint was as good of a character as imagined in any book. 
Shaw had the magic and skill to bring Quint to life. Such a great scene.﻿
comments.author: Eric Long

comments.text:
Spielberg does such a good job here, just letting Shaw tell the tale with 
minimal cuts and motion.  Shaw is so good all you need is him.﻿
